0.title: Dr Aijun Huang (黃愛軍)

1.body: Ph.D. in Cognitive Science , Sep. 2013, Macquarie University, Australia Thesis Advisors: Professor Stephen Crain, Professor Rosalind Thornton M.Phil. in Linguistics , Sep. 2009, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong Thesis Advisor: Professor Thomas Hun-tak Lee M.A. in English Language and Literature , Jun. 2003, Hunan Normal University, China Thesis Advisor: Professor Ning Chunyan B.A. in English , Jun. 1998, Central South University, China
1.title: Education

10.body: Title: Building the First Lifespan Corpus of Mandarin Chinese: Acquisition and Attrition Description: This project aims to establish the first longitudinal corpus of Mandarin Chinese spanning the entire human lifespan. Using parallel behavioral methods (narrative production, picture choice comprehension), we are collecting data from a robust sample of 121 children (3-7 years), 20 young adults, and 71 older adults (60-85 years), with the same children and elderly participants re-tested at 6-8 month and 1-year intervals, respectively. This unique design will create a foundational dataset for tracking developmental and aging trajectories. The first wave of data collection is complete; longitudinal follow-up and corpus annotation are in progress. Manuscripts from the initial cross-sectional findings are in preparation. Postgraduate students: ZHAO Qingwen, NIE Zuyao, HU Shuqi Collaborators: Dr. HU Hai (Department of Linguistics and Translation, City University of Hong Kong) Dr. LI Qun (Audiology and Speech-Language Pathology Center, West China School of Medicine and West China Hospital, Sichuan University) Dr. WANG Rui (School of Computer Science, Shanghai Jiao Tong University) Dr. Yang Wenchun (School of Foreign Languages, Xi’an Jiao Tong University) Title: Acquisition and Attrition of Non-Canonical Word Orders in Mandarin Chinese Description: This experimental project investigates the acquisition (L1, L2) and attrition of non-canonical word orders in Mandarin (including SOV, OSV, and BA/BEI constructions) across the lifespan and in bilingualism. Employing a Syntactic Priming task (production) and a Truth Value Judgment Task (comprehension), we compare native child acquirers, elderly adults (potential L1 attriters) and L2 learners. The goal is to identify the morpho-syntactic and pragmatic factors governing the stability and vulnerability of grammatical representations. L1 Production data collection is complete, and a manuscript is in preparation. Production testing for the L2 learners and elderly adults is in progress. Meanwhile, the comprehension experiment is ready for launch. Postgraduate student: HU Shuqi Collaborators: Dr. FENG Shuo (School of Foreign Languages, Peking University) Prof. BAO Zhiming (English Department, National University of Singapore) Title: L1 and L2 Acquisition of Mandarin verb copying structure Description: This project investigates the acquisition of the Mandarin verb copying structure by native (L1) children and adult second-language (L2) learners, focusing on how verbal semantics constrains its use. The study uses a Truth Value Judgment Task to assess the interpretive comprehension of the structure with verbs from different semantic classes, and a Syntactic Priming paradigm to elicit its production and test for abstract, semantically conditioned syntactic representations. The central aim is to determine how the inherent meaning of a verb (e.g., causitivity) guides and predicts the developmental pathway for mastering this complex syntactic operation across both populations of learners. The experimental component is ready to launch. Collaborators: Dr. Jackie, LAI Yan Ki ( Department of Linguistics and Translation, City University of Hong Kong) Title: Mind, Language, and Narrative: A Training Study in Child Development Description: This project investigated the relationship between language input, Theory of Mind (ToM), and narrative development in typically developing 4- to 6-year-old Mandarin-speaking children. Utilizing a pretest-training-posttest design, the study examined the effects of targeted mental state verb input and direct ToM reasoning training on children’s narrative production and comprehension, assessed via the Multilingual Assessment Instrument for Narratives (MAIN). The research involved designing and implementing controlled training protocols, managing participant groups, and conducting detailed analyses of narrative macrostructure, internal state term usage, and ToM task performance. Findings will contribute to understanding the distinct and interactive roles of linguistic input and socio-cognitive training in fostering narrative competence, highlighting implications for early childhood education and language assessment. Postgraduate student: DU Yu Collaborators: Dr. WANG Rui (School of Computer Science, Shanghai Jiao Tong University)

13.body: Current PhD Students (2): Qingwen ZHAO, Shuqi HU Graduated MA Students (4): Yuting ZUO, Sheng SUN, Xiaomei ZHANG, Jingjing LI Current MA Student (1): Zuyao NIE Selected Undergraduate Advisees: Kangzheng GAO: Supervised undergraduate thesis on child language acquisition. Now continues his research in child language acquisition as an independent scholar, following his PhD from the University of Connecticut, USA. Jingying XU: Supervised undergraduate thesis on child language acquisition. Now pursuing a PhD in the same field at Michigan State University, USA. Yunqi HE: Supervised undergraduate thesis on child language acquisition. Now pursuing a PhD in the same field at The Hong Kong Polytechnic University. Ruihai ZHANG: Supervised undergraduate thesis on second language acquisition. Now pursuing a PhD in psycholinguistics at Shanghai Jiao Tong University.

Ph.D. Thesis title: Acquisition of Polarity Sensitive Expressions in Mandarin Chinese. 2.body: Associate Professor , July 2020 – Present School of Foreign Languages, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, China Visiting Scholar , August 2018 – August 2019 Institute for Language Sciences, Utrecht University, The Netherlands Associate Professor , June 2013 – July 2020 Department of English, School of Foreign Languages, Soochow University, China Research Assistant (Part-time) , October 2008 – May 2013 Macquarie Centre for Cognitive Science, Macquarie University, Australia Research Assistant (Full-time) , August 2007 – October 2008 Child Language Research Lab, Department of Linguistics, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China Research Assistant (Full-time) , June 2003 – July 2005 Institute of Cognitive Science, College of Foreign Languages, Hunan University, China
2.title: Work Experience

3.body: My research investigates the lifespan of Chinese language development, from child and second language acquisition to language attrition in ageing populations, with a focus on semantics, pragmatics, and Chinese grammar.
3.title: Research Interests
